p: Warmer winter temperatures have been associated with WNV across the continental US [ 155, 179], Russia [ 186, 187] and in localized studies [ 160, 191]. Low temperatures are sufficient to halt viral replication (e.g., 14.3 Â°C or below for WNV in Cx. tarsalis [ 44]), although infections in mosquitoes persist at these low temperatures and replication may resume in the spring [ 44, 239]. Thus, it is expected that winter temperatures are acting on vector populations. Other modes of overwintering (e.g., within birds, reviewed in [ 240, 241]) could provide increased capacity for seasonal maintenance that are less sensitive to temperature variation.
